title-group.article-title: Postfusion pullout strength comparison of a novel pedicle screw with classical pedicle screws on synthetic foams

abstract.p: Pullout is a very common failure mode on the use of pedicle screws. Numerous studies were completed to increase the pullout strength of pedicle screws especially for osteoporotic bones. In this study, a previously designed pedicle screw type was tested before and after fusion condition. Synthetic polyurethane foams were used in all tests. Three different grades of foams were used in tests to simulate severely osteoporotic, osteoporotic, and healthy bones. Test blocks were produced and characterized in our clinical biomechanics laboratory. Foaming of polyurethane was accepted as fusion process (bone in growth). Pedicle screw including radial holes (new design) was tested both before and after the fusion. It also exhibited remarkably higher pullout strength after fusion than before fusion and most of other alternatives stated in the literature. In total, 70% higher pullout strength was achieved with new design after fusion. On the other hand, new design did not dominate other alternatives when comparison was carried out on severely osteoporotic and healthy bones. To the knowledge of the authors, this is the first study investigating the postfusion properties on synthetic foams.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Spinal fixation is a widely used solution for patients who suffer from vertebral fractures, tumor causing replacement of bones, and scoliosis.1 Although there are existing fixation techniques, frequently used method for spinal fixation is being operated by pedicle screws.2 Most common problem of pedicle screw fixation is encountered on osteoporotic incidents because of their low bone mineral density (BMD). There are millions of osteoporosis patients around the world.3–5 Much is written about osteoporotic bones and pullout strength comparison, and it is concluded that osteoporotic bones that have low BMD also provide low pullout strength.6–10

Researchers studied on human cadavers, animal bones, and synthetic foams as trabecular bone simulating material to examine the relation between bone and screw.10–12 In addition, numerous numbers of numeric analyses have been considered.12–14 To sum up, key factor of all these studies affecting pullout strength is bone–screw interface.12,15 Bone–screw interface is dependent on several factors such as BMD, screw design, core diameter, and fusion tendency of host bone.9,11,16,17

A typical way of increasing pullout strength for osteoporotic bones is cement augmentation. Previous studies showed that the cement injection significantly improves pullout strength of screw especially in osteoporotic incidents.3,5,15,18–20 Either real bones or synthetic foams are used to observe pullout strength of cement injection in several studies resulting with higher pullout strength on cement augmentation. However, cement augmentation may cause leakage to the spinal canal.21–23 These circumstances have headed researchers to find for different solutions of higher bone–screw interface strength. Many studies have been carried out about screw designs, and it is concluded that conical core performances are better than cylindrical cores in terms of pullout strength.12,24–26 Screw material, thread form, and pitch were also considered, but there were no significant differences.26,27

Another application against preventing early pullout for osteoporotic incidents is using expandable pedicle screws. These screws are formed like an inverse conical geometry inside bones and thus provide unique pullout strength for both normal and osteoporotic incidents.17,28–31 Despite their superior fixation and pullout properties, expandable screws have resulted to be detrimental when revision operations are required.28 Wan et al.29 showed the newly grown bone tissues through the center of expandable screws. This type of bone in growth leads to the higher risk of bleeding on unscrewing. The last but not the least is the catastrophic failure of bone upon back twisting because of fusion (newly grown bone tissue) between the gaps of fins. Resultantly, surgeons avoid using expandable screws in clinical applications due to problematic revision operations.

Demir et al. developed a novel pedicle screw for osteoporotic incidents. Several designs were considered in that study in case of pullout and torsional strength.31 Core diameter, holes drilled normal to the main axis of screw, and distance between holes were examined as various design parameters. Consequently, optimum design was selected like medium core diameter with vertical holes per two pitches through 20 different variations of screw designs according to ASTM F543-0732 and ASTM F1717-10.33 However, this study only considered the starting condition. Postfusion effects were not investigated.

In this study, the influence of radial holes on pullout strength was investigated as in vitro test setup regarding the after fusion effects. Optimum screw design (previously designed by Demir et al.31) and screw without holes were compared. Appropriate polyurethane foam grades 10, 20, and 40 were casted according to ASTM F1839-0834 into die that simulate severely osteoporotic, osteoporotic, and healthy bones, respectively. Die has been designed in a form that screws can be rigidly placed during the foaming of polyurethane. This can simulate the bone fusion into screws. The advantage of bone in growth through the radial holes on the pullout strength was studied in this pattern.

sec.title: Screw design parameters
sec.p: There are two different screw designs. The first screw design was placed so that the axes of consecutive holes were perpendicular to each other. The longitudinal spacing of holes was every two thread pitches. Core of screws was conical. This type of screw was already designed and optimized by Demir et al.31 due to relevant standards in both static and fatigue manner. It was recorded that the related screw has reliable torsional properties and higher pullout strength, thus selected as optimum design. The second screw design has the same size and geometry as that of the first design with the exception of including radial holes and lower core diameter. sec.title: Polyurethane foam production
sec.p: Polyurethane foam is produced by mixing two different components, polyol and polyisocyanate, and is characterized in our clinical biomechanics laboratory. After foaming process was completed, mechanical properties of the foams were examined. This examination was carried out in terms of density and compressive strength of the foams according to the desired grades that are stated in ASTM F1839.34 Die design for foaming and foaming process is given in Figure 2. Screw was fixed to the die, and polyurethane components were mixed in the die. Die was assembled as quickly as possible to create a close volume during the foaming process. This is accepted as the simulation of fusion (bone in growth) through radial holes.

caption.p: Foaming process was realized when pedicle screws were casted into dies as a simulation of bone fusion.

sec.p: A depth of 20 mm is suitable for embedding screw into foam according to ASTM F543. Solidification of the foam was realized approximately 5 h later by mixing the components. ASTM F1839 was considered when producing relevant grades. It is known from the literature that denser foam provides higher pullout strength as it does in higher BMD. Grades 10, 20, and 40 simulate severely osteoporotic bone, osteoporotic bone, and healthy human bone, respectively. Foams were casted into dies in relevant grades for determining the performance of both screw designs in the scope of this study. Mechanical properties of foams are given in Table 1. Bare polyurethane blocks (without a screw) were also casted in related grades to compare before fusion and after fusion properties of screws. Notation used for polyurethane grades is as follows:

caption.p: Mechanical properties of relevant grades of polyurethane foams.

list-item.p: P10: polyurethane grade 10 (mimicking the severely osteoporotic trabecular bone);
P20: polyurethane grade 20 (mimicking the osteoporotic trabecular bone);
P40: polyurethane grade 40 (mimicking the healthy trabecular bone).

sec.p: The term “before fusion” represents the situation of driving the screws through the solidified polyurethane blocks, and the term “after fusion” represents the situation of placing the screws inside the polyurethane mold before the solidification process of foam.

sec.title: Pullout tests
sec.p: Pullout test setup is given in Figure 3. After the solidification of foams, pullout tests were conducted, as shown in Figure 3. Each screw of 20 mm was embedded inside the foam, as shown in Figure 3. Crosshead speed was 2 mm/min. Load versus displacement values were recorded during the tests. Eighty percent of load threshold was accepted as failure criteria (pullout occurrence). This procedure was repeated five times for each and every specimen groups.

caption.p: Pullout test setup: (a) schematic view and (b) photograph.

sec.title: Experimental results and discussion
sec.p: Pullout test results are given in Table 2. The first outstanding result can be declared as radial holes more or less increased the pullout strength after the fusion. T-test was applied to all collected data to understand whether the difference of results between test groups is significant or not. The maximum increment was seen on P20 with 22% (p<0.0005), and the minimum increment was seen on P40 with 2% (p<0.01). Ten percent (p<0.001) increment was seen on P10 after the fusion process. This proved that drilling radial holes normal to the main axis of screw provides higher pullout strength, especially for osteoporotic bones (22%). This is also a promising result due to the fact that bone in growth occurs not only for healthy bones but also for osteoporotic ones. Wan et al.29 reported the newly grown bone tissues after the fixation operations on osteoporotic bones. One can think that osteoporosis prevents the bone in growth. However, Wan et al.29 provided the information about the bone in growth for osteoporotic bones by reporting the newly grown bone tissues after fixation operations.

sec.p: On the comparison of new design and control group by considering the severely osteoporotic bone (P10), new design exhibited 12% (p<0.005) higher pullout strength. Contrary to this, control group exhibited 10% higher pullout strength on healthy bones (P40). For such a comparison, the maximum difference occurred on osteoporotic bone material (P20). An increase of 70% (p<0.001) higher pullout strength occurred on P20. This is also nice to know that our new design provides 1.7 times higher pullout strength than control group for the osteoporotic bones. On the other side, when the bone is severely osteoporotic, our new design only provides 1.1 times greater pullout strength. What is more about our new design is lower pullout strength on healthy bone media. This is mostly due to the increased core diameter. Increasing the core diameter reduces the flat overlap area and the material volume between core and outer diameter. Pullout strength increased 2% with radial holes but also decreased 12% with higher core diameter.

Newly designed screws exhibited 22% higher pullout strength after fusion and 70% when compared to that of control group. Postfusion pullout strength was 2546 N for the new design. Kim et al. also studied with synthetic polyurethane foams as test medium and investigated several screw thread designs. They found highest pullout strength of 2284 N when the screw was pulled out from grade 20 (P20 in this study) polyurethane foam. Our new design provided 12% higher pullout strength than the screw designed and was tested by Kim et al.35 Hsu et al.12 also studied on conical cores to increase the pullout strength, and they declared the higher pullout strength as 2020 N, and this is 26% less than our new design.

A comparison of our new design with cement augmentation is also needed as all these modifications were studied to fix the osteoporotic bones. McKoy and An36 studied the comparison of solid core screws and cement injectable screw on osteoporotic specimens. The highest pullout strength was 2125 N with cement augmentation. Our new design performs 20% higher pullout properties. However, McKoy and An36 studied on both fresh frozen animals and human cadavers. Those samples include bias about the bone quality.

Similarly, Hashemi et al.16 also studied on synthetic foams to investigate the effect of cement augmentation. They used calcium phosphate particulate cement. They concluded that the cement-augmented bone material mimicking the severely osteoporotic bone (P10 in this study) exhibits a pullout strength of approximately 580 N. This is a similar performance when compared to our new design (1%).

All these showed that our new design can be a strong alternative to other methods following the fusion occurrence for osteoporotic incidents. On the other hand, our new design does not provide remarkable improvements for using on severely osteoporotic or healthy bones. To the knowledge of the authors, this is the first study investigating the postfusion effect with synthetic foam materials by considering severely osteoporotic, osteoporotic, and healthy bone mimicking foam materials.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: Main limitation to this study was the lack of living tissues. The comparison of living animal tests and this study would be a great future study. In addition to this, finite element analysis of fusion process can be performed to such testing media.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this study, two different types of pedicle screws were investigated in terms of pullout strength from severely osteoporotic, osteoporotic, and health bones. Polyurethane foam was used as test medium. One of the tested screws was designed to increase the pullout strength of pedicle screw after bone fusion. This screw was tested before and after fusion conditions. It is proved that our new design provides higher pullout strength than most of other methods. This design procures higher pullout strength after fusion for osteoporotic bones. The use of new design does not purvey remarkably higher pullout strength than classical pedicle screws on severely osteoporotic bones.
